This is definitely a GREAT looking game, bar none. The graphics are gorgeous and the soundtrack can be both beautiful and epic (the BWAH of the piece as you enter the gates is magnificent). And although you can see the source of inspiration (Raft comes to mind), the concept is solid. Another well-shown crafting/survival game in limited confines.

That's all the good that is there. The biggest detriment to my enjoyment was the realization that everything was towards nothing. The sinking feeling I got around the fourth or fifth station was that every station is the same...same layout, same expectations, same loot placements. This speaks to a profound laziness in design that spreads throughout the game.

The enemies are all the same...faceless putties that you can massacre with time by just standing outside their travel range. The AI governing their movements is laughable and never presses advantages or is strategic in numbers. The fact that their actual bodies move in the same way every time just gives away the illusion.

The story is probably the other big example of this. I'm chasing a missing scientist, and at 12 hours I still am absolutely no closer to knowing anything. Vids I've seen show islands and other tech advancements (and very stereotypical "battle wave" fights), but even then once they got the train decked out, it was just more of the same. 

I dunno. I love the look, the feel, and the sound, but playing it just feels empty. Look pretty and do as little as possible, I guess.  I am willing to wait the inevitable years-long stretch for early access to churn through, but I don't hold out hope for more unless a drastic rewritting or redesign is made.

PS: and please change the narrator. The epic scope and large vistas of this game are done wrong by a narrator who has been told to sound radio-host/car-salesman upbeat at all times and never quite sound as serious as the game wishes to come off.

[h1][b] Cons/Issues [/b][/h1]

I got this because I watched Markiplier play the demo long ago, and it looked pretty fun. Been waiting on my wishlist until release.
My 35 hours have been defined by three phases:

Phase I:
In the first 10 hours, my impressions were that Voidtrain was a great "comfy" survival experience.
In general, new content (namely locations, mechanics and major story beats) are paced/spaced out very well.
Also, the first 10 hours see rapid tech tree progression because most of the items only require raw materials.

Phase II:
In hours 10 to 20, the player will likely become pretty darn powerful, but some of the cracks also start to show. The requirements for progression grew at a reasonable rate, but producing some of the intermediate components was really starting to get tedious. You have to wait a seemingly arbitrary amount of time for each component you craft at a station. You can get some parallelism going if you have, say, multiple smelters or labs, but the time really adds up.
Combat also starts to show up more and more in this phase. Combat, in particular, needs a lot of work.
1. It's kind of a nightmare to manage all the weapon modules you receive and understand at a glance which ones provide the best upgrade. They easily fill up your inventory, and then some.
2. Gunplay feels really loose. Sometimes, inputs don't register for seconds at a time for whatever reason. It might be designed to counteract spam-clicking, which I inadvertently do sometimes. This gets really confusing because there is a mechanic where guns can jam as their condition worsens, so you can't tell if the game is just ignoring your left-clicking or your gun is jammed. Small idiosyncrasies like that really detract from harvesting resources, combat and building alike.
2.5. Guns jam really easily. I feel like jamming should happen around condition 50%, not 80-95%. But that's just me. All you have to do is press the reload key for your character to fix it.
3. Enemy AI is either completely ignorant of you or has borderline ESP and can hit you from very far away, and there is no in-between. I usually just engage at max distance and it solves the problem, but for reasons that would constitute spoilers that's not always an option.

Phase III:
At this point I have two really powerful primary weapons, easily thwart any threats or obstacles the game throws at me and have a wealth of nearly every resource. Despite all the issues I mention here, the progression does feel really satisfying.
Two of the quests in this phase straight up give you no information about what you're looking for. I spent several levels traveling, not knowing what I was looking for, accumulating a bunch of one particular item and having 0 of another item I needed, and the quest tagline simply says "Find a place to X the Y." Maybe these were obvious to some people, but it's worth mentioning.
If you want a wealth of resources, specifically, I think combat is one of the most efficient ways to accumulate them. That means a lot of time spent frustrated, feeling like you're trying to fight the game to perform proficient combat and tanking while getting beamed from all angles. Hopefully you've queued up your crafts before you start fighting, so you can at least pass the time fighting instead of staring at the timer on the crafting station.
I am nowhere near done with the tech tree (as far as I know), but I wonder just how much more of the game there is. I'll update this review if I change my mind about anything by the time I reach the end.

Voidtrain actively disrespects your time. It tests my patience, and while they have just released an automation update that addresses some of the tedium, it doesn’t address the root problems which are causing most players to quit long before they reach that point. The current build is closer to a first-person idling game than a survival/crafting game.  

In Voidtrain, you are on a train speeding through a surrealist dreamscape full of garbage, alien fauna, and nazis. Here’s where it goes wrong: In other crafting/survival games you have a world of opportunities to interact with. Voidtrain can’t support that; it’s literally on rails. 

Resources randomly spawn in the void and you need to swim over and grab them. It’s extremely tedious because you can only collect one item at a time. There’s not like a pile of wood, there’s just single wood planks. It’s like if Subnautica didn’t have titanium debris, just outcroppings and you had to collect each One. At. A. Time. 

And because you need SO many resources (fuel and materials for each item you make), your super train moves at a crawl the entire time. Having a train in this format is a conceptually bad idea. There's no point in going fast because any kind of speed means you just miss items.  

There are 4 major crafting materials from which almost everything else is built through refining. There are also 4 minor crafting materials for a total of 8 raw materials, these aren’t used nearly as often and are primarily for combat and late-game engine upkeep – moreover they are found floating in the void or from combat. They have addressed this slightly by removing ice from the void so you must synthesize water by building a condenser. However, raw materials are where Voidtrain breaks from the comparison with Raft, which has 10 major crafting materials and 9 minor crafting materials that form the basis of its balance.  

After gathering resources, you have building development. It’s awful. Before you can build a crafting station, you need to research it. To do this, you get either half or all the resources to build the structure… and then those disappear and now you can build it for real. Which means any time you build something, you need to collect the resources to build it twice. 

The big issue here is that, like Raft, this only happens the first time you build something, but in Voidtrain you will only build most items once and the ones you build multiple times you need to make A LOT of (particularly storage and storage racks). You’re not improving on existing designs (like taking an existing item and upgrading it), you’re building a new upgraded version whole cloth. So there is no gratification for researching because it means you have to do all that work again. Likewise, the survival elements are so underdeveloped they can be ignored and the overall resource economy is weaker for it. 

Hunger only affects your health regeneration, so you don’t **have** to eat. If you don’t need to eat, you don’t need to build that garden and now a whole branch of the tech tree is unnecessary. Plus, there’s no drink meter so drinking water (formerly melting ice) has the same effect as growing and cooking but for a fraction of the price. 

Likewise, refining is boring and hostile game design. You craft your metal ingots from scrap then you take those to another crafting station to convert them into a single piece of hardware (bolts, pipes, gears, etc.). It doesn’t work in Voidtrain, but the reason it does work with Subnautica’s wiring kits is because you need different resources – that’s the challenge. Putting iron ingots into a machine that makes bolts and gears (at a cost of 10 seconds per item) is a waste of time by design. 

Put another way, because Voidtrain has a small variety of unlimited resources flying toward you, limited inventory space is the only way they balance against looting everything -- which is why the initial chest only has 4 storage slots. But almost every crafting recipe only uses variations on the 4 main resources, which invalidates the limited inventory space. 

Their workaround to this is turning fungible scrap metal into single-purpose refined parts (created in a 1:1 iron in -> bolts out ratio) that don’t stack so you’re forced to make storage – and by extension collect more resources. So you’ll make gears and bolts, each of which costs a single iron ingot (plus 10 seconds) and are functionally indistinguishable from iron ingots -- emphasizing that the only reason they do this is to make sure you have enough inventory space and also pad the runtime. It would be like if Subnautica made you craft titanium into “titanium sheets” for habitats rather than making them directly from raw titanium. It’s an extra step in the process and only serves to waste your time.

Bigger objects (like the steam engine) don’t need different resources – they just need **more** resources, so you pull in dozens of pieces of scrap metal one at a time with the grappling gun, wait several minutes to smelt them, and then wait several more minutes to convert them into parts. It makes Voidtrain feel like a first-person idling game. Put it this way: Just in crafting time, the steam engine takes 14 minutes of waiting for material processing to research and build. 

Between long stretches of void, you’ll visit stations to do some exploring and shoot space nazis. These depots are light on resources; you can’t break down any of the scenery or take decorations. You open specially marked loot boxes and some resources pop out. What should be an opportunity to reward you for making it through the void (especially because these stations are the only place where you can upgrade your train -- again being balanced around limited storage space) instead becomes a clunky combat diversion before starting over in another stretch of void nearly indistinguishable from the last one. 

Since space nazis don’t often appear in the void, there are also Space Sharks to randomly attack your train. The problem is the UI is far too clunky for these kinds of encounters, making combat better situated to dedicated battle zones. Fitting with the “Voidtrain hates your time” theme, each tool has its own draw and sheath animation before the actual menu pops up, during which time you’re locked out of anything else – which is annoying --  and drawing your weapon has its own animation and firing delay. So, if a space shark attacks and you’re building something, you have 3-5 seconds where you can’t do anything to stop it. 

And that’s Voidtrain’s gameplay loop. Every part of it feels designed to waste your time. Voidtrain’s rail system and crafting system are each artificially slow and the gathering system is fundamentally repetitive and tedious. If that sounds fun, by all means; but this feels closer to a proof of concept.

Boy howdy, this is a tough review for me to write. I've bought this game twice now, spent about 100 hours in it between Steam and Epic, and yet I still don't know whether or not I recommend other people buy it. 

Voidtrain is an enjoyable game to be sure, but it has been designed in such a way that the gameplay has a hard end to it. You have 33 phases to your research table, and once you've finished those, there's basically no reason to keep gathering stuff and therefore not much reason to keep playing the game. Your train caps out at 12 wagon platforms (not including the 4 that make up your locomotive) so there is very much a state of "final evolution" that the train cannot grow past, and that means there is no real creative endgame as once you have achieved the optimal layout for your 12 wagon platforms, there is little if any incentive to invest the effort of tearing down your train one platform at a time to redesign it or rearrange the order of your cars. You get about 20-30 hours of thoroughly enjoyable gameplay (plus however much time you spend decorating your train at depots), then you are coasting through the void on a train that can't grow any bigger, ignoring most of the resources you are passing by, doing combat arenas and occasionally stopping to follow fireflies out into the void, all for resources you don't even need anymore.

And none of this bothered me when I played the game two years ago on Epic, but this is also functionally the same game I played two years ago. Two years ago we had 33 research table phases, 12 wagon platforms, two locomotive engines, and our side content in the void consisted of the firefly puzzles, abandoned trains, guarded outposts, combat arenas, and train to train combat. The only things they have added in two years of dev time have been the story about the scientist, and the Rofleemo based automation and the associated stations. So the gatherer's station, the cleaner's station, the trainkeeper's station, etc. Turrets are new. The rams are actually new since the last time I played. There have been some QOL changes, like the fact that enemies no longer spawn on the platform that you arrive at when going to a depot. Now they have their own little designated combat area. That's all nice.

But it doesn't even come close to providing an actual endgame. And I understand that the game has unique limitations being, quite literally, on rails. But I feel that survival games like Raft show us that we can have niche settings to where and how we are building but still have accessible and even wacky options for endgame. There's ultimately no real reason why our train can't be so long that the engine reaches the end of a void sequence before the final car has actually left the previous depot, but it is nonetheless a thing that cannot be done, and I feel like the game suffers greatly for it. As charming as the rofleemos and the narrator and the scientist story all are, I would trade all of it in a heartbeat for a removal of the building cap on train wagon platforms.

I always hate saying negative things about smaller studios because it just feels like kicking down, and I want this game to be everything it has the potential to be, but it kind of feels after two years like the devs are more concerned with things like narrative and presentation and even production value over things like content and endgame. Well, I have officially burnt my entire weekend away playing this game. Guess I'll say everything I like about it, along with a few minor nitpicks.

Visually, the game is impressive, especially for an indie company. On "Epic" settings, you can see grains of wood, pits on the metal, etc. The devs put a lot of love into making the game look good, and it shows. Despite being an indie survival game with amazing graphics, it even still runs well! Putting out a near-perfect 60fps using DX12 and all the highest settings on a 3060ti. Good optimization is important to me, and this launched with it. 

The sound design is phenomenal. The guns sound punchy, and actually have different sounds depending on how you build them. I am a sucker for good sound design, and the sounds of this game are satisfying when they need to be, and when they don't need to be, they're downright eerie. The soundtrack is also dynamic and epic, filling me with chills every time I pull into the depot. I do feel the witch chest sound cue puzzle SFX are a little out of place, but that's nitpicking. Besides, those goofy ahh sounds match the humor the game continues to provide.

Voidtrain is rich with personality. Sure, you control a thus-far muted character who has to give all their personality via first-person cutscenes, but this adds a lot of charm to the game. This genius engineer is also a complete idiot, which as someone who has worked in IT, is hilarious to me. My theory is some of the devs have done exactly what the engineer does: take out a hammer and beat something with it until it works. Hilarious! Genuinely gives me a smile every time I see it. There's also aliens/enemies outside of yourself, and a wise-cracking narrator to feel even a solo playthrough feel... less so.

I love the narrator's voice and lines. The dialogue feels natural, not forced, which is a great feat considering this game is about a train flying through triangular portals in between reality. The fact I am immersed in such a ridiculous setting is a testament to convincing personality and writing. Props to the narrator by the way! They did a fantastic job.

As for game mechanics, I do admit, in the first hour or two, resource gathering can be repetitive. You jump off, mash E while looking at some boards, bring back to ship, build, rinse, repeat. Typical survival gathering... until you get the "grappling hook." This little tool changes EVERYTHING. You can now break a resource rock, fly off the train, snipe like 5 items with your grappling hook, and swim back in no time at all. This already makes the resource gathering WAY quicker. Plus, shortly after that, you unlock prophecies. These make the resource spawn rate increase, which makes it so you get the materials you need even faster! But other than the resource gathering being slow at first, which is usual for this genre, the game mechanics are diverse and entertaining. Can't appreciate speedy gathering if you first don't get through the slog!

Shooting feels decent, and I love experimenting with different weapon parts to make my gun preform differently. The enemies range from dumb to "wow this guy is armored, I need a lot of rounds to take him down," and even having things like boss aliens with varying attacks and armor plates you need to shoot off. Considering this game is a survival game first, and FPS second? I think they did a fine job making the shooting parts entertaining.

Building your train is fun as well. I was encouraged to keep doing so since pets are such great buffs, and you need more wagons to get more pets. There's plenty of motivation to progress, and so far, after thirty hours, I haven't even reached the limit. I don't even think I'm close, looking at other trains in the game, and seeing all their upgrades... I'm sure I can get those as well. Just gotta keep grinding. I love the varied ways you can build your cabins on the platforms. The train editor is intuitive enough so that it only takes a few moments to understand, but complex enough to allow for a vast amount of combinations to make it look perfect in your eyes. As for placing furniture, such as chests and workbenches, I do wish there was an option to toggle snapping... but the placement system is precise enough to allow for perfect alignment, if one spends a few extra moments with it.

I did try co-op with a family member, and, other than the fact it made progression way faster than it should be (we got a grappling hook from scratch in 55 minutes and we weren't hardly trying)... it worked pretty much perfectly! Though, fair warning, you can't no-clip through teammates, so getting around the starter trolley feels a bit cramped at times. That's honestly the only "bad" thing about MP, and it's easily prevented by user error avoidance.

Overall, this is one of my favorite moving-base style survival games, if not my favorite. I definitely feels worth the price. It's well-paced, well-written, intuitive, smooth, and beautiful. It has captured my attention for every waking moment of this past weekend, and I am not ashamed to say so. I'm sure it will for many more hours after. I love trains, and I love space. This combines both. 9.5/10, near perfect, only a few small nitpicks mainly concerning quality of life luxuries.

[h2]This is my story...[/h2]

Boring and grindy as hell, don't buy it.

No problem!
Just click on the smelter; then on fuel; then on wood; then the right arrow how much wood you want to put in (max 10); then click out, click on the resource you want to smelt; click the amount in; click out; click on the hammer icon.

[b]Edit[/b]: Well, good news. They changed a lot of things and addressed several of my complaints. There are still flaws, but it's not nearly as grating as it once was.

Voidtrain can be a little frustrating. Not frustrating in that it's difficult, not frustrating in that it's glitchy and poorly made, nor frustrating because there's anything in the game that is overtly offensive. It's frustrating in that there are some really good elements in here but it feels like the developers wanted to focus on... well, literally everything else.

[b]TL, DR[/b]: Voidtrain has some serious identity issues. It says it's an open world survival crafting game, but there's no open world and no survival. Just crafting and shooting and gathering. No exploration, minimal player agency. There's promise there but it seems the developers got carried away at some point with feature creep and are now building what is essentially a looter shooter with tedious crafting, amazing music and as little player agency as possible. It's not a bad game by any stretch but right now it seems to be trying to be everything and not quite succeeding at all of them.

The Good
 - The Void and 90% of the stuff in it. It's ominous while being peaceful, there's a teensy bit of (unfortunately linear) exploration which feels really awesome, especially the first time. My only criticism of it is that there isn't really any threat in said void. The creatures present are effectively harmless despite trying to be implemented like Bruce from Raft. 
 - The music. Oh man the music. Mwah. Perfect. 10/10. Approaching the gate for the first time is just fantastic and every time it triggers I enjoy listening to it. Combat music is good, too, and there's plenty of peaceful stuff for when you're just collecting. 
 - The puzzles. They're weird, quirky, and just the right level of tricky. Even when you know how to solve them you still have to figure them out so it's all reasonably satisfying.

The Not-So-Good
 - Rofleemos. Yes, I know, ha ha meme pet. It doesn't fit - even remotely - with anything else in the setting. Every time you interact with them it's like a scene out of Who Framed Roger Rabbit with a cartoon floating around in a realistic setting. They're not going to get removed either so hopefully you really like them.
 - The Narrator. Again, it feels like they're going for a Stanley Parable or Breathedge sort of thing here but the game is neither comedic enough nor the narrator charming enough to make it fit. Removing the narrator would unironically improve the quality of the game as environmental storytelling is much, much more effective and immersive than a snarky disembodied voice breaking the fourth wall constantly.
 - The FPS. You remember I said the game was FPS-Crafting? Yeah. The FPS is... not great. Every bullet has significant travel time, the iron sights seem wonky at best and while the AI and fighting is alright on its own, it's not satisfying enough to carry the entire game. This would be totally acceptable if this was an open world survival crafting game with lots of other things to do, but the shooting is instead a necessary focal point for most of what you do and just can't shoulder that burden yet. 
 - The crafting. Woof. Early on it's alright but the further you go the more complex the recipes get and eventually you need to have 3-4 steps for every different material. You don't have enough to mass-produce them, they take a long time to craft, often require fuel resources in order to craft, and when you're putting everything together it just feels like busywork after a while. Might be wise to look at games like Grounded for examples of similar but more satisfying crafting. Having us refine everything into infinity is not, in fact, very fun. Collecting a broader number of resources, or gathering and consuming them in larger quantities, is probably a better way to go. [b][This seems to have been mostly addressed/fixed][/b]
 - The Arena. A necessary side quest but as it is currently balanced the big "shield" enemy is wonky AF. They've added a marker indicating where its attack will land, but this doesn't matter because you can only dodge it if you are already sprinting by the time it appears. Walking, strafing, and sometimes even sprinting will not evade it. It turns battles into a literal test of how much damage you can soak rather than how skilful you are. 
 - Weapon modding. It's... well, incredibly tedious. The weapon modifiers are unclear at a glance so you don't know what you're picking up until you've already nabbed it and gone back to the train. But even this doesn't really matter because ammunition is sufficiently limited that you want to maximize your per-shot damage so you don't have to go through multi-step crafting to waste resources on it. It could be significantly simplified to be a bit less burdensome (especially on your inventory as each gun hypothetically has 6-7 pieces) and ideally less of a looter-shooter.
 - The train. Early on it feels fantastic, very Raft-like. Very tense and eerie, evoking the sense that you are tiny and alone in a huge void. Then you start expanding, and the number of things you need in your train start expanding. Then you have Rofleemos randomly appearing on the ground blocking movement. You have other players blocking movement. Then you have nice-looking modules that add walls and ceilings... and a tiny door that it is comically easy to block other players from moving through unintentionally. If the train was 1-2 steps wider it would probably be great, but as it stands your train rapidly becomes cluttered and if you're not playing alone you will frequently be in each other's way. If nothing else the developers need to make it so players can pass through each other or push each other out of the way. Also it [i]desperately[/i] needs some form of internal lighting available by default. None of the wagon sections are usable in the slightest without light. [b][They recently added lights early on and spread out the cosmetic/decorations in a good way][/b]
 - The content, or absence thereof. Yes, it's still in early access so this is only a minor gripe - but at the moment the majority of the game occurs in the void and there's not really a whole lot they seem to be able to do to make it interesting or engaging. Just some busywork with mines, mostly. Fighting other trains is exciting, but other than that it's peaceful gathering. 
 - Player agency. If you want to insist on calling this game open world you need to empower players to make decisions and explore. Not follow an oblique path to a predetermined outcome - to actually set out in a direction and forge their own path. You could do this by creating forks in the tracks, having broader sets of rocks that players can jump between with clusters of materials or rewards amongst them, etc. Prophecies are alright but the impact is so negligible on most of them that they might as well not exist.

So is all hope lost? Well, no. Do I regret my purchase? No, not really. I do enjoy the game - if I didn't I wouldn't be quite so frustrated with it - but it does seem like the developers are fumbling a bit with the direction. Or fumbled with it and made some questionable decisions. Either way the direction seems set now and, unfortunately for me, it seems unlikely to change dramatically in the future.

The framework of the combat system is there and functions reasonably well, though the arena fights fall into the same trap that a lot of games do by throwing melee enemies at you and forcing you to awkwardly backpedal while firing your weapon and repeat. The gunfights especially feel thrilling, terrifying, and extremely satisfying when you pull off a cheeky maneuver--the blockade gunfights and train battles take place in a zero-G environment, and it's possible to swoop, launch, fling, or otherwise traverse around the enemies in dynamic and novel ways to get the drop on them. The gun crafting system is somewhat opaque, but honestly I feel that's for the best--Voidtrain avoids the metaphorical penny on the tracks of infinite optimization of weapons to fit a meta, and instead gives you multiple viable and powerful options and variations. I'd love to see some more long range combat options in the arsenal, and I'd love to see the enemy soldiers integrated into some less structured environments out in the void as well to really push the limit of the encounter design as well as interact with the other enemy types.

Some elements of the gameplay are obviously still building up steam in the development process though the core loop of resource collection, inventory management, processing, and upgrading the train is generally satisfying.
